3758: Aladdin's Ring.author: DarthParallax
3758: Aladdin's Ring.text_parsed:
One word. Fireball. Channel has better uses. :P

However! It IS pretty neat that this card is colorless. I like the ideas of both Aladdin's Ring and Rod of Ruin, just, of course, they seem to be too weak. It's not just that they are ''slow'' because good control decks can use high CMC cards anyway. :P


There is some Design out there that makes this type of card actually Good, I just don't recall seeing WOTC print it yet :) I would recommend they start by adding 'this damage can't be prevented. If a creature is dealt lethal damage this way, it can't be regenerated.'


I like Anti-Regeneration clauses. I also like that WOTC has pulled back on them. I want to see Anti-Regeneration clauses carefully used as Pepper, a spice you don't need to see everywhere instead of as Salt that is so ubiquitous it stops being special and starts being Assumed. It would be cool to flavorfully associate a card as ''In World extra-powerful'' by adding a clause that In Game is not usually powerful. :)


(I think this card would be vastly improved by changing 8-8-4 to 6-6-6 :D )

3759: Amulet of Kroog.author: DarthParallax
3759: Amulet of Kroog.text_parsed:
You know....the more I look at old cards, the more I REALLY appreciate how much of a difference

1 CARD
1 P/T
1 LIFE and 1 MANA

really make. Even though this card is quite slow and some might fairly say over-cost, a) it's a common and probably useable in Limited, though bad. b) the numbers do not need to be changed very MUCH to transform this into rather an annoying little actual piece of Protection.

Imagine if it drew a card every activation? Broken. What about just 1 card ETB? Becomes Playable.

What if either the casting cost or the activation cost 1 less? Playable. BOTH? Becomes a good card, probably squarely uncommon-good.

What if it blocked TWO damage? What if it blocked damage and gained 1 life instead?


This card IS weak...but oohhh sooo clooose x)

3765: Battering Ram.author: VDZx
3765: Battering Ram.text_parsed:
@Burningsickle
Clearly you're not familiar with the rules of banding. You attack with the Battering Ram banded to a creature (the creature 'carries the battering ram'). Then you get blocked, and you divide the damage as you choose (see: banding): If the creature carrying the battering ram was strong enough to survive battle with the glory seeker, both the carrier and the ram survive. If the glory seeker happens to be stronger than the creature carrying the battering ram, you have the choice of either letting the carrier die (but keeping the ram safe) or abandoning the ram to save the creature.

The only flavor oddity here is that you can somehow still get your ram back even if the carrier dies in the clash, but otherwise the flavor is solid.

In other words,
*Soldiers are depicted only for illustration and must be purchased separately.

3769: Clockwork Steed.author: Aaron_Forsythe
3769: Clockwork Steed.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #44, 12/6/10

Clockwork Steed is one of ten artifact creatures with “Clockwork” in their title. Clockwork Gnomes from Homelands doesn’t really resemble the others, so I’ll talk about the nine that all share the lose-counters-then-wind-up functionality that Mr. Steed here has.

The first such creature, Clockwork Beast, appeared in the very first Magic set, Alpha, and from talking to people that were playing back then, the card was beloved. I can see why--the flavor is quite good, and you get a creature that starts out bigger than Craw Wurm for the same amount of mana in any color deck.

As with many Magic cards, when something is liked, it gets turned into more cards. Clockwork Avian showed up in Antiquities, and Homelands brought the Steed and its near-twin, Clockwork Swarm. The Steed and the Swarm have identical rules text, except one can’t be blocked by Walls and the other can’t be blocked by artifact creatures. I find that a bit weird--I don‘t usually think of a horse and a bunch of insects being the same size, and I think making them so similar was more confusing than cool.

In fact, by the time Homelands was done with them, most of the cool had been sucked out of Clockwork creatures. The Beast and the Avian were rare and offered decks size in ways most colored cards could not. But the Swarm and the Steed were merely common. They had a “been there, done that” feel and didn’t fit into the set mechanically.

For some reason, the bloated Fifth Edition Core Set contains almost thirty Homelands reprints, including this card. It appears that there was little rhyme or reasons to the choices, so I’m refrain from commenting on the reprinting.

Those initial four Clockwork creatures all had the same template: a bunch of +1/+0 counters that were removed after attacking or blocking, and an upkeep activated-ability that allows you to re-buy the counters up to the number they started with. While that’s fine flavor, and a reasonable story for a single card (maybe two) to tell, it is awfully clunky.

The newer Clockwork creatures from Mirrodin (and Time Spiral’s Clockwork Hydra) cleaned up the text a bit, using +1/+1 counters and either letting you wind them up as much as you wanted (albeit slowly, like Clockwork Vorrac and Clockwork Dragon) or not at all (like Clockwork Beetle and Clockwork Condor).

Ultimately, all these cards are kind of fun, relatively flavorful, but awfully fidgety and not very good. There is certainly room for cards like these in the game, but, as with anything, they can be over done.

3769: Clockwork Steed.author: willpell
3769: Clockwork Steed.text_parsed:
I loved the Clockwork creatures and believe that the first two along with Clockwork Swarm were perfectly executed. The Steed's immunity to artifact creatures makes no flavor sense but made the card an MVP for my Johnny purposes, making it unblockable with things like Thran Forge or just slapping Fear on it and sideboarding swampwalk against black.

Mirrodin's Clockwork creatures were all crap. Worst homage ever. If Wizards isn't willing to use +1/+0 counters anymore, then I'd just as soon they didn't try to make Clockwork dudes, as using +1/+1 counters for them feels all wrong. And the Condor was the absolute worst - it just dies after a few attacks, without even starting out oversized like the Beetle. I like the clockwork archetype, but it might be that Magic just can't do justice to it anymore under the "unified counter types" paradigm.

3769: Clockwork Steed.author: alextfish
3769: Clockwork Steed.text_parsed:
FWIW, I disagree with willpell. I thought the move from +1/+0 to +1/+1 counters was very sensible for the re-envisaging of Clockwork. willpell didn't even provide any reason why the simpler and far more common +1/+1 counters were worse than the +1/+0 counters except "it feels all wrong". I fear you're getting a bit blinded by your own subjective nostalgia there.

Admittedly most of the Mirrodin clockwork cards were bad; the only modern Clockworker I've used much has been Clockwork Hydra along with untappers, which was fun, and Clockwork Dragon which kept coming up in drafts. But the Mirrodin clockworkers were very, very far from "worst homage ever". Time Spiral has many candidates for that undesirable honour.

3771: Coral Helm.author: blurrymadness
3771: Coral Helm.text_parsed:
Card advantage is sometimes in the form of lands. When you have a hand full of lands (such as a large Treasure Hunt) you can use this to non-randomly (essentially) add a good bunch of damage.

The issue is that this is a dead card:
-In multiples
-When you have no such advantage
-When you have no creatures
-When you don't have enough mana to pump your creatures enough to compete

It's also still card disadvantage; although it's virtual card advantage.

3785: Gauntlets of Chaos.author: BastianQoU
3785: Gauntlets of Chaos.text_parsed:
Imagine a pair of gauntlets appearing before you, just floating there. Before you can figure out just what they're doing there, they clasp around your wrists, and lift you off the ground. Slowly, but faster and faster, they carry you across the plane, where you meet the eyes of your master's enemy. The gauntlets drop you at the planeswalker's feet. As you collect yourself, preparing to fight, the gauntlets form themselves around your hands and arms, molding to your shape. You go to strike at the planeswalker, but the gauntlets hold you firmly in place. Meanwhile, the planeswalker is looking you up and down, his face full of a growing disgust.
"I lost my Chimney Imp to this useless thing? Son of a..."

3788: Helm of Chatzuk.author: Scottevil912
3788: Helm of Chatzuk.text_parsed:
Back in the day, I would open these and be so annoyed that it wasn't a better card. I would use them as throwing stars with friends.

Fast forward 10 years and now I see the amazing power of this card.

One of the weaknesses of banding was that it A.) it was limited to pretty much white creatures and B.) they tended to be smaller weaker creatures. (the complex rules didn't weaken the ability, just made it confusing)

The helm is the perfect because it circumvents the two major weaknesses that existed.

Take Saprazzan Heir from Mercadian Masques - a 1/1 for 1U that when it attacks and is blocked, you draw three cards. If it is blocked, it will likely die.

Use the helm though, and give the Heir banding, now band it with a large creature and your opponent has to determine if it's worth blocking the large creature to give you 3 cards or take a large amount of damage.

3788: Helm of Chatzuk.author: Aquillion
3788: Helm of Chatzuk.text_parsed:
This is a much better card than people are saying. Defensive banding allows you to use a few chump blockers to kill something bigger and only lose one of your 1-drop chumps in exchange. Offensive banding allows you to attack with a beatstick banded with some expendable trash and not worry about whatever they block it with.

Banding lets you control what you trade off, exchanging your weaker creatures for your opponent's stronger ones (or leaving them in a situation where they can't block or can't attack respectively, depending on how you use it.) It's a versatile and powerful ability if used right.

3788: Helm of Chatzuk.author: OlvynChuru
3788: Helm of Chatzuk.text_parsed:
Just because banding is complicated doesn't mean that the card is bad, guys. The great thing about Helm of Chatzuk is that it can give banding to creatures that don't suck.

@DrJack

How about you find some smart friends of yours who don't know how banding works, teach them the basics of Magic if they do not already, then show them the reminder text for banding on the gatherer. After that, ask them what would happen in the specific situations which are unintuitive (such as if you attack with a flying creature and banding creature and you band them together, can a creature without flying block the band). See how often they are correct.

My point is that Banding has problems, and it doesn't have to do with Wizards being condescending (at least not in the case of banding)

3790: Infinite Hourglass.author: yyukichigai
3790: Infinite Hourglass.text_parsed:
This card is just pure joy for a Johnny. So many possibilities, especially because it only boosts POWER, not toughness. You can use it with something like Powerstone Minefield or Caltrops, along with Indestructible or "protection from" creatures, to keep your opponent's creatures unable to attack while yours maraud at will. Combos well with things like Spikeshot Elder. Attack with a Stuffy Doll and watch your opponent's head explode.

Another interesting aspect of this card is that it very specifically uses "time counters", i.e. the same counters used for suspended cards. This provides some very fun interactions with cards like Jhoira's Timebug or (even better) Timecrafting. With an Infinite Hourglass out, Timecrafting basically reads "all creatures get +X/+0".

Finally, it's a great "political" card in multiplayer games. People may help keep you alive just because their Ornithopter comes out as a 7/2 for Zero mana.

EDIT: Fun question: what happens if you use Jhoira of the Ghitu to suspend the card? Does it affect creatures while suspended? I wouldn't think so, and yet cards like Pardic Dragon have text which works while suspended.

EDIT: Fun question: what happens if you use [autocard]Jhoira of the Ghitu[/autocard] to suspend the card?  Does it affect creatures while suspended?  I wouldn't think so, and yet cards like [autocard]Pardic Dragon[/autocard] have text which works while suspended.

3800: Mana Vault.author: theelk801

3800: Mana Vault.text_posted: @Megrimage: The reason they've errata'd it is because "end of upkeep" isn't a triggerable event. Things can't trigger at the end of a step because the end of a step is only when the stack is empty and priority is passed in succession. It just doesn't work as a trigger.

3803: Nevinyrral's Disk.author: Aquillion
3803: Nevinyrral's Disk.text_parsed:
The reason it broke the game with Necropotence wasn't because it let you start drawing normally again; that was just a nice side-benefit. The reason it broke the game was because by the time you play Necropotence and the disk, your opponent has usually played most of their starting hand (as have you).

Then you draw another hand with Necropotence and blow up the field with the disk, and they have no way to respond as you bring that new hand out and murder them with it. It completely breaks the flow of the game in a way that even Wheel of Fortune or Timetwister didn't. Even if you effectively manage to get a +7 out of those, your opponent is at least guaranteed to have some way to respond to what you drew. With Necropotance + this, your opponent simply loses.

Even if you effectively manage to get a +7 out of those, your opponent is at least guaranteed to have some way to respond to what you drew.  With Necropotance + this, your opponent simply loses.

3811: Skull Catapult.author: TheMurderousKitten
3811: Skull Catapult.text_parsed: In today's game, yes, this is too expensive. When it was released, it was actually a decent card, since there were not a lot of ways to have your creatures do direct damage at that time. The beauty of this card was that it was colorless, which opened up options for colors other than to do some direct damage. The game tended to be much slower back then, so you could spend on this sort of thing and actually have several turns to use it. Artifacts were actually somewhat rare back then, unlike today. This card now is only valuable for the nostalgia it creates.

3822: Abyssal Specter.author: DarthParallax
3822: Abyssal Specter.text_parsed:
To be truthful, Specter is a tribe with a direct mechanical identity "we make you discard lots of cards" that is at least as powerful as Elves "we make you lots of mana", and no amount of redundancy on Specter cards even TODAY really goes by without gratitude.

But back in the days of 5th Edition, a VERY important card existed in large numbers, continually reprinted in sets like Ice Age, the Core Set, and maybe one of the other "Old Sets" from Arabian Nights-Fallen Empires?

Dark Ritual.

This card is therefore 5 stars with no valid arguments available: it is Hypnotic Specter 5-8 plain and simple.

3823: Animate Dead.author: Anzu-chan
3823: Animate Dead.text_parsed:
In case it took you two or three times to understand the oracle text :

"When you cast this spell, target a creature in any graveyard.

When Animate Dead enters the battlefield, put target creature on the battlefield under your control. Animate Dead gains the Aura type and "enchant creature put onto the battlefield with Animate Dead". Attach Animate Dead to the creature put on the battlefield by this card.

Enchanted creature gains -1/-0.

Whenever Animate Dead leaves the battlefield, sacrifice enchanted creature."

3823: Animate Dead.author: DarthParallax
3823: Animate Dead.text_parsed:
one of the most TOP DOWN designs in Alpha! :D

I know it will likely be a looong time before we ever see this again in Magic STANDARD....but never say never? :)

I think there may come a day when they would allow us to have it in the Core Set. After all, they brought back LIGHTNING BOLT, and I think Black is owed a COOL OLD REPRINT.

It's special rules and Enchantment Type make it Very Destroyable, AND the creature isn't given any buffs or protections....AND Dark Ritual and Hymn to Tourach seem Even Less Likely to be reprinted in Standard ever again.

Hymn To Tourach could be a Rare though. :P

3824: Ashes to Ashes.author: MacBizzle
3824: Ashes to Ashes.text_parsed:
If you want to hit Darksteel Colossus, try Return to Dust.

As far as this, to hell with suicide black. Hallow.

@Kryptnyt:

Hallow is better used AGAINST cards such as those. Spending mana on your own Earthquake or Chain Reaction and THEN Hallowing is not advisable, as Hallow prevents all damage from a spell, and the purpose of those spells is to kill all your opponents' creatures. And using Hallow on this is not like using a card to gain 5 life, it's like using a card to gain 10 life. You have to remember, you're nullifying the self-destructive part of this spell and THEN gaining 5 life as a topper. In this deck that I have, with a full playset of Ashes to Ashes and a full playset of Hallows, I also run two CoP: Blacks. A deck full of self-damaging black things (such as Flesh Reavers, Kezzerdrixes and this) is the only way I can justify using such a narrow card as CoP: Black. The Hallows are there as a cherry on top. For 1WBB, I have exiled two non-artifact creatures, negated the punishment for having such a cheap and powerful spell, and gained 5 life. Or, I could be prepping that Hallow in case my opponent has an infinite fireball combo up his sleeve.
3824: Ashes to Ashes.text_posted:
If you want to hit [autocard]Darksteel Colossus[/autocard], try [autocard]Return to Dust[/autocard].

As far as this, to hell with suicide black. [autocard]Hallow[/autocard].

@Kryptnyt:

Hallow is better used AGAINST cards such as those. Spending mana on your own Earthquake or Chain Reaction and THEN Hallowing is not advisable, as Hallow prevents all damage from a spell, and the purpose of those spells is to kill all your opponents' creatures. And using Hallow on this is not like using a card to gain 5 life, it's like using a card to gain 10 life. You have to remember, you're nullifying the self-destructive part of this spell and THEN gaining 5 life as a topper. In this deck that I have, with a full playset of Ashes to Ashes and a full playset of Hallows, I also run two CoP: Blacks. A deck full of self-damaging black things (such as [autocard]Flesh Reaver[/autocard]s, [autocard]Kezzerdrix[/autocard]es and this) is the only way I can justify using such a narrow card as CoP: Black. The Hallows are there as a cherry on top. For 1WBB, I have exiled two non-artifact creatures, negated the punishment for having such a cheap and powerful spell, and gained 5 life. Or, I could be prepping that Hallow in case my opponent has an infinite fireball combo up his sleeve.

3824: Ashes to Ashes.author: Kryptnyt
3824: Ashes to Ashes.text_parsed:
@MacBizzle
If you use hallow on this, its like using one card to gain 5 life. Circle of Protection: Black would be preferable, and Hallow is better used with things like Earthquake and Chain Reaction.
Edit; My point was, if you were using hallow on a mass-damaging spell, you would gain enough life to force your opponent to find a different way to kill you than through damage. Using Hallow when you cast Ashes to Ashes is the same as just casting a big Healing Salve, and it takes away from the function of the card. Ashes is good because it is a 2-for-1. Ashes+Hallow is only a sorcery speed 2-for-2 at four mana. It just doesn't get me excited.

3833: Carrion Ants.author: DoctorKenneth
3833: Carrion Ants.text_parsed:
If you're playing black, you might as well play a Shade. But if you absolutely MUST play a Shade-like mechanic in a thouroghly multi-colour deck, I guess this would be it. Yes, the Shades cost less, but the colourless activation is fairly helpful. Again, in mono-black, that point would be invalid.

Since it's compatable across colours, it might fit well with a casual black/green strategy, using some handy green acceleration to get to scary numbers before any removal comes out. But, that said, the amount of resources you'll need to sink into it would probably be better spend on big green creatures. Even though you can't use the Shade tactic on a solid green creature (that is to say, leaving mana open on the attack and pumping it just enough after blockers are declared to keep it alive, or pumping for big damage if it's not blocked), other creatures have more than enough benefit to compensate, for similar costs.

Anyway, if you're running it, be smart with your lands. Never pump it until the last possible moment. Don't sink more mana into it than you need to. And when deciding if you should run this or any other Shade-like creature, ask yourself: Is the chance of large damage worth the mana you'll be investing? Is it worth holding back on playing certain spells to put the mana to use here? Do you have the means to protect it or replace it when you are low on mana? If so, then by all means.

Please reprint this I can't wait to enchant this on a Tormented Soul

And you can put multiple copies of this card on the same creature, at minimal mana cost. This card is insanely powerful on a black-blue control deck. Turns your innocent looking creatures into nightmare fuel in no time, will force your opponent to use kill spells on your drops. You either counter their answer or throw them away before they can play it. If the opponent have lots of creature removal I will wait until my counters are ready. 3842: Evil Eye of Orms-by-Gore.author: A3Kitsune
3842: Evil Eye of Orms-by-Gore.text_parsed: Magic has had a number of odd creature types that were only on one creature. "Evil Eye" ranks up there among them, especially as it's so specific - it's not just an Eye, it's an <u>Evil</u> Eye, and they had to make that clear to seperate it from all the non-evil Eye creatures WotC ended up not printing. Makes you wonder what other types of Eye creature they were thinking of making.

3842: Evil Eye of Orms-by-Gore.author: Opeth2010
3842: Evil Eye of Orms-by-Gore.text_parsed:
I just love the flavor of this card. It's such a scary card. It's like you command one of your minions to block it, and the eye's terrifying gaze paralyzes your creature, rendering it unable to block, and the eye just floats by, towards its victim...the planeswalker. Muhuhahahahahah...

Maybe not the most efficient unblockable creature you could play, but I give it 4 stars for the deliciously evil flavor.

3848: Gloom.author: Sumai4444
3848: Gloom.text_parsed: This card has seen so much play over the years, professional and casual tournaments as a side board!Usually the first or second pick for anti-white sideboard back in the day!Definitely a 4.5 as far as sideboards go, even if only a 1.5 star card as a staple card in a deck.Making it an average 3 star card overall! The best tournament I ever saw was some guy who had built a deck around when IceAge first came out. I don't remeber the build, but he decided to exploit Power Sink effects in a Black/Blue. I remember Homelands was allowed in that Tourney, and the spread he had out was sick! 3 Glooms, an Irini Sengir, a few Mole Worms tapping out land, a Koskun Falls, a couple of Seizures on the few creatures that made it into play, an Icy manipulator, then for the kill a couple Norrit on the table poised to untap his small army of Prodigal Sorcerer and Zuran Spellcaster's he had in play. Not to mention the Power Sink's he seemed to always draw to add insult to injury! Talk about a tournament to rember. He placed second, he lost to a mono red burn deck, but still! Gloom as a sideboard against the many white decks made the difference for sure!

3849: Greater Werewolf.author: Mode
3849: Greater Werewolf.text_parsed:
Has anyone heared yet that Werewolves are going to be a tribe in Innistrad? Pretty cool, huh?
The only weird thing about this is: apparently it's going to be the one.

I find that weird for multiple reasons:
There exist three werewolves so far, which are all black for obvious reasons. Having them as R/B or G/B tribe would have been more sense. But for Innistrad the five "allied color" combinations were used, and black was already taken by Vampires () and Zombies ().
Werewolves (at least right now) use the creature type Human Wolf.
Greater Werewolf used to be a Lycanthrope, but that term just unifies these two types in its etymology.
And notably any seemingly aberrant types that weren't replaced in the Grand Creature Type Update by Wizard was kept intentionally so far, like Kithkin, Pest, or Spawn. Lycanthrophe, however, was.
So that would suggest that Werewolves in Innistrad also use the types Human Wolf, and their tribal effect would probably affect Wolves.
But since the tribe is Human, they could easily be put into that tribe as well. Now you might think "Well no surprise, Human is a a very common race type that's often found on other tribal cards - Soldiers, Wizards, you name it!"
So this was possibly intended, but that would be contradicting: it never was the tribe itself. Now that this changed, Wizards seems to have intentionally kept that usually common type away from the other tribes, since each of them is a different race () Ghosts (Spirits) being the fifth one). Which could mean we'll get Lycantrophes afterall.
Maybe they didn't want to choose Beasts because that's usually not the type of intelligent race that can talk and act deliberate (which is true for all Innistrad races). But an anthropomorphic beast tribe would have been pretty to come up with. Werewolves seem to be the closest thing to that, and probably they were also chosen to follow that "Vampires vs Werewolves" trope, meaning each of those tribes will have hate (cards) against the other one. Don't get me wrong i find this tribe interesting as well, but it would have made more sense to me to have the most typical tribe instead of another one that would normally kill to be black. Or become black when it kills, for that matter :P

I got my information from 5ColorControl, which sums up my thoughts about this in a funny comic:
http://www.5colorcontrol.com/comic.php?comic=149

Oh well. I guess it's a good thing though that Goblins were not chosen to be that tribe for once.
Despite being a Goblin lover, i honestly think they were used far too often, showing up in every block, always as a common and most often even as one or the main race of red creatures.
Only Humans can claim the same (but as mentioned before, without any tribal use), and Wizards when just focusing on appearance in blocks. Both of those types however aren't tied (as much) to a single color like Goblins. Even Elves can't compete with that, since these didn't exist on Kamigawa for example.
Magic designers can't just always make cards for the same players. Possibly they kept making all those Goblins because aside from their huge fanbace, they also have indeed very red flavor and keep providing some sort of comic relief.
But if their realm now gets stopped for once in Innistrad by Werewolves after 16 years, it's about time!
And although Beasts didn't get any tribal love since Onslaught (the oldest tribal block), we constantly kept getting new Beasts. Not many players were probably asking for Werewolves, but they're actually a pretty cool tribe to look forward to despite all that, likely with new refreshing characteristic mechanics.

3857: Lord of the Pit.author: tezcat
3857: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed: Xathrid Demon would probably be the better choice, but only if you're planning on keeping him happy with sacrificed creatures. Keep in mind that Lord of the Pit will not tap like Xathrid Demon if you fail to meet the sacrificial requirement. This means that Lord of the Pit can be useful in situations where Xathrid Demon is not, and in decks focused on life-gain (to overcome the damage) rather than creature-token generation (to prevent the damage effect from triggering). Consider also that Lord of the Pit's effect is damage (which can be prevented), while Xathrid Demon's effect is loss-of-life. Spirit Link, for example, counteracts the lord's drawback, but would have no effect on the Xathrid's (and would not prevent it from tapping, in any case).

3857: Lord of the Pit.author: Morgaledh
3857: Lord of the Pit.text_parsed:
This is the card that made me want to start playing this game. First, I just love saying "Lord of the Pit." Then there's the artwork... nothing like it, man. As far as the suicide aspect, dying to this thing because I wasn't able to control it was so flavorful that it was almost ok. I mean, I started playing D&D/AD&D back in 81, so I got that if you summoned a demon and screwed around with it, you'd die. No cacodemon spells here. And when I didn't die, but used my summoned fiend to crush my opponent? All was right with the world.

This card isn't about what is better and what is worse. This card is about, well, this card. And it has to be a 5/5, because this is Magic, and it's a Lord of the Pit.

3865: Necropotence.author: Mike-C
3865: Necropotence.text_parsed: Who here remembers "Black Summer"? Haha if so, doesn't getting old suck? Those that don't, here's a hint.. I'm knocking on 30's door, but the very 1st MTG game I ever witnessed (which would end up being the one that forever changed my life) was in July during Black Summer. I had just turned 14 & was in 8th grade summer school study hall watching 2 nerds play this crazy card game (I can say that because I am one :) and so a Red splash green Burn deck was just obliterating the other dudes Mono-Black & then, he pulled the Necropotence, spent like 5 of his last 6 life leaving him with 1 & ended up swinging for 20 damage in 2 rounds for the W. I'm sure it comes as no surprise that my main deck would go on to be a black splash white for nearly an entire decade! Ive owned a lot of bada** cards between then & now but never the dominating necropotence, ironically.. I think I'll get 1 just to say I did. Yep.

3870: Pit Scorpion.author: Salient
3870: Pit Scorpion.text_parsed:
Plenty different from infect, and in interesting ways. Note that Scorpion still does its regular 1 damage in addition to the poison counter. Also, it doesn't need to do combat damage in order to deliver its poison payload (so you could use something like Quicksilver Dagger with it).

Scorpion wouldn't deliver more poison due to Giant Growth type effects, but it also successfully delivers a poison counter when unblocked even if its power is reduced to 0 (for the same reason that Xantid Swarm has a cool effect even when not buffed).

3870: Pit Scorpion.author: Arachnos

If you want to see powercreep in action, compare this to Ichorclaw Myr.

Ichorclaw costs 1 mana less, is colorless (compatible with any deck), has a Wither effect against creatures, becomes 3/3 when blocked or attacked.

Pit Scorpion... I guess it deals one damage to players as opposed to only a placing a poison counter, I guess. And it's immune to Doom Blade?

3870: Pit Scorpion.author: DarthParallax
3870: Pit Scorpion.text_parsed:
Poison is a good mechanic, and I'm glad MaRo decided to push it in Scars of Mirrodin Block. :)

I also agree with the camp that thinks it was maybe way too much for Standard. That's why it was so smart to use it with Phyrexians. Then the Horribleness of it is actually FLAVORFUL and you appease a small percent of the haters on that note. :P

Overall, for Legacy, Modern, Casual, and EDH, we have about as much Poison as the game needs, I think now. It would have been fairly tricky to find a way to sneak in that much Poison one card at a time and actually enable Poison Decks. A Poison Block was needed, and I consider the Standard and Limited environments of Scars of Mirrodin Block to be Sacrifices to making Poison as good as it deserves to be in the rest of the formats. :P

As an interesting curio, there are only roughly half a dozen Scorpions in Magic. I personally think they, along with Spiders, ought to be retconned in a second Grand Creature Update to be "Arachnids", since right now Spiders are being called Insects and that is frankly just too wrong-- it is such a common misconception that one way or another I REALLY want to correct the Spiders, and "Arachnids" seems the most elegant. However if we just had "Creature type- Spider" added, I suppose that would be 'ok', but the game wants to support Tribal Synergies as much as possible, so splitting Insects, Spiders, and Scorpions into three Tribes would be somewhat awkward.

An Arachnid Lord though? That would be frigging awesome, and could be designed to be Very Different from an Insect Queen :D

3871: Plague Rats.author: longwinded
3871: Plague Rats.text_parsed:
As fjdkslan has said, you used to be able to construct a deck of 20 plague rats (and for that matter, 20 Dark Rituals). Both of those cards are a BIG reason you're only allowed 4 of any card today, since neither card was not powerful enough to ban/restrict.

Originally, high cost/slowness was the only thing that made them balanced. When the new rules nerfed them, Pestilence Rats were added as a way to recapture some of their swarming ability in a card that was useful even with only one on the field. Relentless Rats is a similar attempt to bring back swarming with creatures that are useful even with only one on the field.

The rulings could use a better example. For instance, a player at 4 life would lose 2 life since 4/3 = 1.3333 repeating. This example makes it more clear that you do not round to the nearest whole number (5 would result in a loss of 2 with either operation, so it is a bad example).
Again, this is just a player's interpretation so believe it at your own expense.

3872: Pox.author: blurrymadness
3872: Pox.text_parsed:
Use when you have a clean third (0,3,6) and when your opponent does not (1,4,7.)

Why? Because the rounding up means you'll lose 1/3rd but they'll lose between 42-50%, and that huge difference in symmetrical cost will cause massive card advantage for you.

For instance, playing 2 cards per turn means that on T3 you'll be at 3 swamps and 3 cards in hand when you cast this, which means you'll lose a creature, a land, and a card in hand.

Your opponent however will lose 2-3 cards in hand, will lose a creature, and 1-2 lands; a 4-7 cards loss. This means you either 3-for-4 them or 3-for-7 them. It also pushes you towards a win-con, which is a big deal. Small Pox works nicely as well. Consider recurring creatures in your deck (Nether Traitor is a good start) and things that dodge this (Bloodchief ascension, artifacts, quest for the nihil stone, nihilith) and creatures that benefit from it (Tombstalker)

3877: Sorceress Queen.author: Pennyforth
3877: Sorceress Queen.text_parsed:
Just played in a tournament for the first time in years, and ran into this oldie....and the way my opponent was using Sorceress Queen, which was backed up by the man in charge of the tourney, was that its ability is effectively the same as Humble/Ovinize/Sudden Spoiling--i.e., that a creature targeted by the effect loses its abilities along with the change in stats. I'm curious if this is the official ruling on how Sorceress Queen works, because I had, and still have, trouble accepting that, for two reasons:

--Humble, Ovinize and Sudden Spoiling all explicitly state that they alter the target's power/toughness and remove its abilities, while the text for Sorceress Queen states only the stat alteration--and in fact, the Arabian Nights and Revised printings both state that "special characteristics" are unaffected.

--Having been introduced to Magic back when Revised was in print, I have no recollection of this card ever being used to both alter stats and remove abilities. If it has now been decreed that Sorceress Queen does both, it would be far more than a simple rules update or clarification--it would be adding an ability to the card that it previously did not have based solely on a ruling, one that is contradicted by the earliest printings of the card.

The reason this came up was that my opponent attempted to use his Sorceress Queen's ability to save it from death by my Prodigal Sorcerer's well-known tap ability. It was his assertion that since (according to him and the tourney boss) the S.C.'s ability works like Humble/etc., and he used it in reaction to my attempt to ping the S.C., he negated the ping ability by negating it on the stack. However, Gatherer rulings for both Ovinize and Sudden Spoiling both say that their effects do not counter abilities that have already been triggered--so even if an S.C.'s ability works like those cards' abilities, it still should have taken the ping and been killed, leaving a temporarily 0/2 Tim behind (staring at his buddy, the Suq'Ata Firewalker, and saying, "So this is how it feels to have no combat damage to deal!"). Right?

I suppose I'm just being nitpicky, since I beat the guy anyway, but it kind of annoys me to think that I got bigfooted on something that didn't sound right to me from the get-go.

3877: Sorceress Queen.author: stuzzicato
3877: Sorceress Queen.text_parsed:
I love this card. I usually played it alongside Royal Assassin. Even though they don't necessarily have a particular synergy with each other, their ability to completely shut down any offense is virtually unparalleled for their cost.

One funny thing about Sorceress Queen in particular is the permanent confusion that seems to surround her ability these days. Doubly funny is that Wizards themselves created this confusion by updating first her card text and later her Oracle. Everyone, if you ever have a question about Sorceress Queen, just look at the original printed text and how she works will become crystal clear. Her original text: "Tap to make another creature 0/2 until end of turn. Treat this exactly as if the numbers in the lower right of the target card were 0/2. All special characteristics and enchantments on the creature are unaffected." Turns out to be pretty simple, huh?

3877: Sorceress Queen.author: Antsache
3877: Sorceress Queen.text_parsed:
@Guest

The Queen doesn't remove abilities, so your opponent could very well pump Shivan Dragon in response to her ability. He could also wait until her ability to resolve, then pump. Finally, any pump triggers that were already on the stack, but had yet to resolve when the Queen's ability resolved would still occur. The Dragon would become a 0/2, then gain all the power it would normally get from any of those pumps.

The only one I'm not entirely sure on is pumps that resolved before the Queen's ability. My guess is that the Queen's ability still wouldn't counteract those, because they're essentially +1/+0 counters that last for a turn only. The buff doesn't disappear as a result of the Queen's ability, so the dragon becomes 0+x/2 for the turn, where x is whatever buffs have been applied to it. The only sort of "buffs" the queen's ability can counteract are ones that are phrased exactly like hers is, "Creature becomes x/x until EoT," as whichever effect resolves last will override the previous one in that case.

3877: Sorceress Queen.text_parsed:
Quick summary of rules on this card:
No, it does not remove abilities. Even if it did, it would not counter abilities already on the stack (such as prodigal sorcerer's damage).
No, it does not remove the effects of buff enchantments, equipments, global buffs, or counters (those apply after the creature becomes 0/2).
No, it does not remove "until end of turn" buffs, since those are applied after power/toughness setting abilities (this changed in m10).
No, it does not prevent you from buffing a creature above 0/2.

Pretty much the only things this does hit are */* or "copy" cards. Those effects are applied before effects that set power and toughness.
If you have other effects that are setting power or toughness (such as tezzeret), those are applied in the order they were played (timestamp order).

3881: Thrull Retainer.author: Radagast
3881: Thrull Retainer.text_parsed: A decent card back in the day since it was one of the first creature enchantments that was designed to try to get around the card disadvantage produced by using such enchantments. Later experiments led to the "bounce" enchantments that showed up in Mirage, Totem Armors, etc. So, at least from a historical viewpoint, this card is worthy of note.

3889: Xenic Poltergeist.author: Mode
3889: Xenic Poltergeist.text_parsed:
It has a somewhat interesting synergy with Sword of the Meek.
When the Poltergeist enters, the Sword returns and makes him a 2/3.
Then in your opponent's turn you can turn the Artifact intro a 2/2 creature (which will unattach the Sword from it - you can of course use the ability to unattach equipment in genral) and sacrifice it for whatsoever.
This way the Sword can be used as additional creature saccing fuel whenever a 1/1 creature enters each turn.
And it can also have great use for destroying your opponent's -mana artifacts, like artifact lands such as Seat of the Synod, Moxes, Engeneered Explosives or Chalice of the Void.
Overall I like this guy regarding combos more than Karn's Touch.

3891: Aether Storm.author: Tanaka348
3891: Aether Storm.text_parsed:
Another gift from Homelands.

This card isn't actually good. You're getting a 4 for 4 version of Lava Axe, which was never great in the first place, but your opponent can not die instead. Sure, you've locked down his ability to play creatures, but you'd have been better off with a card that would have actually killed him instead. It's off color, but that doesn't make it that much better. On top of that, you can't aim the thing in a multiplayer game, and it'll whiff if your opponent's deck is creature poor too.

The only thing that saves it from utter worthlessness is silly Pithing Needle combos.

You get this down fast enough, and it won't matter anymore- they won't be allowed to resolve EVEN if you don't have the Counterspell in your hand.
Their Only Hope?

to give a BLUE deck REACH at a competitive 4 damage on Turns 4-6! Which even though it's not spectacular, it helps it KEEP up with the amount of violence other decks can produce.


The shell of the Weissman Deck is naturally powerful for a ton of reasons, and Aether Storm itself isn't going to be pushing that deck further along, but IF you don't have a Moat, instead of looking at what the card can do for the deck, you can look at what the deck can do for the card and say that The Deck can REALLY take Aether Storm absolutely as far as it can possibly be pushed, which is something :)

3897: Brainstorm.author: tavaritz
3897: Brainstorm.text_parsed:
This has nothing to do with Scry 3 & draw one card. Thsi lets you draw three cards and put any cards from your hand on top of the library. Scry doesn't give you any cards, but it let's you put the cards you're looking at the bottom of the library.

So cry 3 & draw a card let's you draw only one card but it van be any if the four on top of your library. This doesn't let you draw the fourth card but this let's you keep all three you draw. Much more powerfull than Scry 3 & draw.

3899: Dance of Many.author: MadMageQc
3899: Dance of Many.text_parsed: Note that just like Faceless Butcher and Oblivion Ring, this  works wonders with effects that can return permanents you control to your hand at instant speed, such as Vedalken Mastermind's ability. The Oracle text has the same kind of wording as Oblivion Ring : one comes-into-play ability and one leaves-play ability.  If you respond to the comes-into-play ability by returning Dance of Many to your hand, the leaves-play-ability will trigger, go on the top of the stack, and resolve first. When it does, it tries to remove the copy token from the game, but since that token hasn't been created yet, it doesn't do anything. Then the comes-into-play ability resolves and creates a token that is completely independant of Dance of Many. If you replay Dance of Many, it's a whole new enchantment that doesn't remember its affiliation with that token, and that won't force you to sacrifice it if it leaves play again (and vice-versa). There you go, one unbound clone per turn !
3899: Dance of Many.text_posted: Note that just like Faceless Butcher and Oblivion Ring, this  works wonders with effects that can return permanents you control to your hand at instant speed, such as Vedalken Mastermind's ability. This card indeed isn't affected with M10's mana burn rulings in any ways.
But nontheless this spell is pretty useless:
You'll rarely get even the mana back invested into casting this spell. If your opponent is playing a somewhat useful Sleigh deck, he/she'll be tapped out most of the time anyways. If your opponent is not tapped out, he/she has likely saved the mana for something different which will get use as soon as you cast this spell.
Seriously, most of the time you won't profit from casting this.

3908: Flood.author: Mode

Really flavorful at first glance, but when you think about it, the flavor is a bit weird actually. The flavor text of this card even supports this thought:
Let's say there are three Goblins in front of you, how are you supposed to flood only a single one of them?
Floodgate for example makes more sense here if you ask me.

With the revival of blue aggro control, this could actually become a pretty choice for a reprint.

3913: Homarid Warrior.author: Tiggurix
3913: Homarid Warrior.text_parsed: As it is already a mediocre creature, it might be a little pointless, but I think that Second Wind would go together quite well with this guy. It can give itself shroud, and thus naturally protect itself from targeted removal, making it less of a risk in terms of card advantage to play an aura on it, and Second Wind can untap it right after it makes use of its ability and on its 'submerged' turn, as the aura untaps as normal. Of course, there are much better targets for the enchantment, among them Deep Spawn, this card's larger cousin, so it's quite a weak combo overall.

3913: Homarid Warrior.text_parsed:
Remember that Shroud wasn't a thing when this card was published; Wizards overestimated how much it would be worth.

Also, remember that its ability is slightly more powerful than it seems -- despite the high cost, if your opponent targets it with a card and you use its ability, that's a +1 for you. Because most players will be unwilling to risk that, its ability is often just as good as Shroud. The blue mana is usually a bigger problem than the fact that it taps itself and stays tapped.

It's still a terrible card, mind, but that's mostly because it's 5 mana for a 3/3. If its ability was on a creature with a non-ridiculous casting cost, it'd be great.

3917: Krovikan Sorcerer.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
3917: Krovikan Sorcerer.text_parsed:
This is an interesting wizard. In a deck without black, he is almost strictly worse than a Merfolk Looter, since he costs 1 more, and since you have to discard before you see what you're drawing.

If you're using the second ability, though, he's helping you dig pretty quickly for a 3-mana creature, and he doesn't look quite as bad.

Naturally, as a flavour geek, the card appeals to me. This is one of the first cards I saw that explicitly encouraged playing two colours together, and his powers become more impressive if he dabbles in "the black arts". I have to give him a thumbs up, even though these days he looks very outclassed.

3922: Magical Hack.author: tenkaze
3922: Magical Hack.text_parsed:
This can change basic lands into other types, right?
I'm pretty sure it can, since the color of mana a basic land produces is dependent upon its name and type (see Dryad Arbor, Murmuring Bosk, the cycle from Shadowmoor, etc). So a permanent named Island with the type Basic Land - Island will be changed to Forest / Basic Land - Forest, and therefore tap for green mana.

@lateralisone: Okay, but type line is text, and a basic land's abilities are defined by their type. So you could get an Island / Basic Land - Forest that taps for green mana if I'm understanding this correctly.
But then again, if this can't change name, it might not change type line either ... however the Oracle wording says "text," not "text box", so I'm fairly certain that you would at least be able to change the type of a basic land with this spell.

edit: From the rulings: 10/4/2004 - It can be used to change a land's type from one basic land type to another. For example, a Forest can be changed to an Island so it produces blue mana.

The lesson to me is to check the rulings before asking, and the lesson to lateralisone is to read the rulings before shooting people down.

3926: Mind Bomb.author: DarthParallax
3926: Mind Bomb.text_parsed:
It was a rare in the Dark. For some reason some retard in Development decided this would be good as an Uncommon in Fourth and Fifth. This would be a Mythic today. A Banned in Standard and Modern Mythic. This card is so retardedly overpowered, I now see what R&D means by complaining that Old Blue got too much Color Pie.

I mean, of course Old Blue was too powerful, but I didn't think it had an unfair share of mechanical devices. I now see I am completely, 100%, as wrong as it is possible to be, because this card should never be mono-colored of ANY color that's how much power AND utility it has. Also should cost 3 times as much mana and be about 5 times as Rare in Limited.

Actually, this card in unsalvageably WRONG. Just think: If this were an Instant, we'd have our answer to What could POSSIBLY be more undercosted than ANCESTRAL RECALL??!
Yep. This could have been the Blue Boon.
Check out my comment on The Dark printing, too :)

3932: Power Sink.author: Khardiss
3932: Power Sink.text_parsed: I have this from the 5th Edition.  I never realized until I just now read the Oracle that it actually forces your opponent to tap lands whether he wants to or not.  The way it's written "counter target spell UNLESS that spell's caster pays an additional X" always led me to think that if my opponent didn't want to pay X, he could opt out of it and the spell was just countered.  Knowing that this card forces him to tap his lands whether he wants to pay X or not completely changes how this card gets played.
3932: Power Sink.text_posted: I have this from the 5th Edition.  I never realized until I just now read the Oracle that it actually forces your opponent to tap lands whether he wants to or not. 3939: Sea Serpent.author: Radagast
3939: Sea Serpent.text_parsed:
Landhome cards have always bugged me since they really make no sense.

Technically speaking, a blue mage is not actually sitting in the ocean or on an island during a duel. He's wherever the battle is, which could be anywhere and is not in any way defined in the game. The Islands he calls upon to summon creatures are merely the source of his mana, but they could be on entirely other planes. The Sea Serpent shouldn't care at all who has Islands... and don't get me started on how randomaly applied the Landhome ability is! Argh!
3939: Sea Serpent.text_posted:

3939: Sea Serpent.author: jfre81
3939: Sea Serpent.text_parsed:
Have to keep perspective of what the game was like in Sea Serpent's day, and particularly the state of blue at the time. Any blue fatty of the day were both expensive to cast and had a serious drawback - Leviathan, Polar Kraken, you name it. Most people's blue creature-based decks were almost invariably built around merfolk, not big beaters, although they may have been in there as finishers.

If you like the flavor of islandhome, you can build a deck around it. There are several blue spells (e.g. Spreading Seas and abilities (e.g. that of Reef Shaman that can give an opponent an island. High Tide and Saprazzan Skerry for a bit of mana acceleration in a traditionally slow color. Instead of Sea Serpent, use Vodalian Serpent which with kicker is 1/1 stronger than this for the same CMC. The counters can be proliferated too.

Who knows, you might even win a game here and there with such a deck. :o

3945: Sleight of Mind.author: yyukichigai
3945: Sleight of Mind.text_parsed:
Not quite rendered obsolete by Mind Bend, which has more flexibility but only affects permanents. Not as good as Spectral Shift, even with the increased cost. Unless you have specific spells in mind to alter (like Seedtime) and need the low cost you're probably better off running Bend or Shift instead of this.

Regardless, this is a fun little spell and the genesis of many a budding Johnny. It's always fun to watch a deck built with this card, Magical Hack, Whim of Volrath, and Mind Bend. Even if you lose, it's probably going to be in some really creative way. For general play though this card is a little too difficult to use effectively.

@Villano137: That combo doesn't actually work, because Blue Elemental Blast and Red Elemental Blast both require the target to be Red/Blue on declaration, before Sleight of Mind can be cast. However, it does work with Hydroblast and Pyroblast, which have the all-important "if" clause in there that let them target any spell or permanent, but only do something if it is the right color.

3948: Stasis.author: Mode
3948: Stasis.text_parsed:
According to the cards Borgomastro refered to, his comment was actually really quite useful.
But i also agree with thaviel, this is english based and intended to communicate accordantly, even if you don't get to choose the card in other languages since it's only available in english in this case.
Yet like this you can't really discuss, since you'll talk past each other effectively. I'm also native german and if anyone really insists on writing a non-english comment on an english card, he should really only do so with an accordant english translation.

Now, finally to the card:
Since this card won't be really effective unless you build a deck around it.

Frozen Æther can be used to ensure that everything your opponent could come up with enters play tapped.
If you don't have Stasis out, Winter Orb will slow down the game as well and serve as soft-lock to keep most of the lands tapped.
Destroy your opponent's nonbasic goodies by using Wasteland.
Consider using Force of Will because, you know, contering spells without paying mana was never a bad idea.
Bounce effects like Boomerang might be handy in a Stasis deck as well.

Then there is a bunch of cards that let you return (tapped) islands and put it into play untapped again, providing the mana for paying Stasis' upkeep.
Daze works as free Force Spike/softcounter that returns one island.
Thwart is quite similar, with the difference that it's a hardcounter and you have to return three islands.
Further mana-free, island-returning cards that might help keeping up paying the upkeep cost are Ensnare and Tidal Bore, which return two (one) islands and tap all (one/untap one) creature/s.
There's still one further card of that type with the downside that you have to pay three mana for its morph cost at first, being Fathom Seer. But aside from that, he provides two cards after turning it up and a 1/3 body.

Forsaken City works nice with that card, since you can virtually simply discard a card rather than desperately having to find free mana.

Vedalken Mastermind is a further card that works just awesome with Stasis. Use his ability to return stasis to your hand before your turn starts, and then simply cast it again. This should be the easiest way to keep your opponent restricted from Stasis while you just have to keep three blue mana open for the combo and aside from that do whatever your heart desires.

And if you want to make a green-spash, you may run Garruk to untap an island for the stasis upkeep and use the other untapped land for something different each turn to slowly surpass your opponent. His other abilities - creating 3/3 beasts and generating an Overrun effect - should help doing so as well. Downside is he requires double-green mana which might causes some problems with aforementioned island-returning cards.

Talking about finishing the game, you will needs something different than Garruk if you want to harm your opponent somehow.
Morphling shouldn't be a bad choice and is extremely versatile.
Serra Sphinx, effectively being a vigilant Air Elemental, can do a nice job as well.

Well, that's pretty much all that flows in my mind concerning Stasis decks so far, have fun building your own one (if you want to)
Maybe you want to do something creative and include Trade Caravan for the lulz :D

3948: Stasis.author: ClowWizardEriol
3948: Stasis.text_parsed:
From reading articles about Wizard's early days, there was not creative director that could provide guidelines to how the art should look, and many of the artists were locally contracted. So, the "inconsistency" in early Magic artwork probably came from the artists interpreting only from the card name.

For a generically named card like Stasis, I don't mind the abstract art.

3950: Time Elemental.author: Mode
3950: Time Elemental.text_parsed:
In a monoblue deck you'll probably prefer Temporal Adept.

I like the flavor from this card though. Despite the fact that this creature has 0 power and you'd really only want to block with this card when you desperately needed to, the ability will trigger if you get into any kind of combat. You could call it a chrono trigger :P
I'd translate this as "do not mindlessly interfere with time and space, or bad things will happen."

I'm not sure whether there's a thought like that within the non-enchantment restriction. You could interpret that magically enhanced objects are freed from the boundaries of time and space, but then it wouldn't make sense again that you can just bounce enchantments directly.

So i guess this was really just a functional restriction meant to keep players from destroying auras by bouncing the permanents they enchant, because this card was only meant to 'rewind' spells.

I'm not sure why it's exactly 5 damage (and 2 toughness) though.
t would have been cool if you'd flip a coin when it dies instead, with the chance of getting 5 life instead if you win. Because of the unpredictability of time travel, you know :D
3950: Time Elemental.text_posted:
In a monoblue deck you'll probably prefer [autocard]Temporal Adept[/autocard].

I like the flavor from this card though. Despite the fact that this creature has 0 power and you'd really only want to block with this card when you desperately needed to, the ability will trigger if you get into any kind of combat. You could call it a chrono trigger :P
I'd translate this as "do not mindlessly interfere with time and space, or bad things will happen."

I'm not sure whether there's a thought like that within the non-enchantment restriction. You could interpret that magically enhanced objects are freed from the boundaries of time and space, but then it wouldn't make sense again that you can just bounce enchantments directly.

So i guess this was really just a functional restriction meant to keep players from [i]destroying[/i] auras by bouncing the permanents they enchant, because this card was only meant to 'rewind' spells.

I'm not sure why it's exactly 5 damage (and 2 toughness) though.
t would have been cool if you'd flip a coin when it dies instead, with the chance of getting 5 life instead if you win. Because of the unpredictability of time travel, you know :D

3951: Twiddle.author: kitsunewarlock
3951: Twiddle.text_parsed: A classic. It protects you from damage, gives you a blocker, lets you use that creature's tap ability twice, ramps your mana with cards like Tolarian Academy, Sol Ring or just Tron. It protects you from counter-spells by tapping out your opponent's last island, you can put it on Scepter to get an Icy Manipulator on crack. It lets you use your artifact again and de-activates artifacts like Winter Orb or Howling Mine. There have been many variations of this card, many of which are a tad stronger. But Twiddle will always maintain its status as the first.

It lets you use your artifact again and de-activates artifacts like [autocard]Winter Orb[/autocard] or [autocard]Howling Mine[/autocard].  There have been many variations of this card, many of which are a tad stronger.  But Twiddle will always maintain its status as the first.

3963: Birds of Paradise.author: liir007
3963: Birds of Paradise.text_parsed:
Card of the Day - Friday, March 29, 2002
The Birds have been one of the staples of the game since it began, but they were created as an afterthought. Their art was originally supposed to be for Tropical Island, but the bird was too prominent. So Richard Garfield created a card just for the art, and it ended up being the most versatile mana-producing creature ever.
--Also the creature type was 'Mana Birds', modern versions are just 'Bird'

3966: Chub Toad.author: WrinKtontaf
3966: Chub Toad.text_parsed:
After running out of draft boxes, some friends and I decided to build commons decks to play until M15 comes out. As I was going through boxes of cards I came across the chub and said "yep, that's going in just because of the name." I've owned chub toads for nearly 20 years and have never played one. Until now.

I really don't understand the low rating here. It's certainly not a great card, but it's certainly not a bad card either. Expensive for a 1/1, yes, but in a pauper format, assuming it doesn't get zapped immediately, it's either going to get its one damage through, or it's going to eat a 2/2 or 3/3 that tries to block it. And it's a great chump blocker that will eat a 3/3.

I will say this proudly: Two chub toads and a goblins of the flarg won a few games for me last night.

Beyond that, I give 5 out of 5 just for the name and art.

@moleland, @nope.avi

If you're putting 6 walls/elves in front of this to kill it, how much damage are you taking from the other creatures that you aren't blocking? Plus, unless one of those walls has 1 power, you still won't kill it. You need to put SEVEN guys in front of this just to drop it. If you have seven creatures held back on defense for this thing, then you're losing.

This thing also blocks as normal, so it's not all bad. Sure, he's expensive for having such a negative ability, but I think that if they re-released this guy in a new set and had him cost 2GG, he'd be playable.

3989: Johtull Wurm.author: BastianQoU
3989: Johtull Wurm.text_parsed:
@Peabody:
You are correct about needing 7 to kill it through its own ability. For everyone confused, the ability doesn't trigger for the first creature blocking it. Although it would take just 4 to make it harmless.

@Dolorosa: You are quite mistaken. The ability just lasts until the end of the turn, so becomes a 6/6 again the next turn. There's nothing permanent about this card's ability besides death.

Thinking about it, this card could have been good if it was printed as black. But green has way too many efficient creatures that completely outshine it.

3993: Lifeforce.author: Mr_Hendry
3993: Lifeforce.text_parsed: In many cases it was better to just have a few copies of Avoid Fate in your deck. Nevertheless this is a unusual green card and useful for that reason. I agree that Painter's Servant is excellent in combination with this card. In fact, I think that there is no better combo for this card. The concept of combining this card with Omnath, Locus of Mana is also awesome. I would guess especially in mono-green or with a few copies of Wild Growth and an Overgrowth or two. That way you won't have to stress to much about playing the balancing game with the risk of your Omnath getting depleted. You could also through in a Deathlace just in case; especially if you're playing any copies of Dwan's Reflection or Fertile Ground.

3993: Lifeforce.author: Salient
3993: Lifeforce.text_parsed:
Link > Ganon

Autumn Willow > Baron Sengir

I am sad that there is not a third _____force, because I would have liked to be able to assemble the Triforce.

Note that Deathgrip/Lifegrip can be a subtle choice for Painter's Servant combo. I prefer Lifegrip, because it's possible to run mono-green, and Avoid Fate is a powerful protective counter for protecting your Servant or your Lifegrip before assembling the combo. On the other hand, if you're inclined to go all-in on the Grindstone combo strategy, black has better tutors (e.g. Grim Tutor).

The main problem with that is, if you're going all in with Grindstone, don't run green or black, instead run blue, red, or blue-red.

(If you've seen Painter's Servant + Grindstone and you're wondering why anyone would try anything else, a single sideboard card like Gaea's Blessing or Blightsteel Colossus can ruin the combo. Against people who run Emrakul, Progenitus, or Blightsteel Colossus, you have to hope to land an instant-speed draw spell before the shuffle effect triggers, which sounds easy but isn't. And right now, Progenitus is one of the most commonly used creatures in Legacy, because he can be cheated in with Natural Order...)

Oh. That reminds me. If you choose "green" with Painter's Servant, you run the risk of letting your opponent play Natural Order sacrificing a nongreen creature like Vendilion Clique. Choosing "black" doesn't make creatures nongreen, but at least it doesn't help them get a Progenitus! That's why I prefer Lifeforce to Deathforce.

3995: Living Lands.author: Mr_Hendry
3995: Living Lands.text_parsed:
This was the second to last printing of this card and I suppose it has seen its hay day come and go. Nevertheless, it was always a fun card and worked well with mono-green when you always had a lot of forests out to cast your big green monsters.

Life and Limb is of course strictly better and really usurped this Living Lands place in magic. Oh well.

This card would be fun with Hunting Wilds and Murkfiend Liege if you didn't have any Life and Limb's handy. Watch out for cards like Rank and File or especially Reign of Terror.

The art is absolutely inferior to art used up through Forth Edition for this card.

3997: Lure.author: DarthParallax
3997: Lure.text_parsed:
To really PROPERLY answer this question is going to take a bit of setting up, just because I want to tell it as a nice story :3

OK, so first, this is the *Fifth Edition* copy of the Lure card.

Vth came out close to the release of Chronicles, and because of these two sets we have the Reserved List. As you may know, Chronicles reprinted a number of valuable cards, specifically from Legends.

What almost NOBODY knows about the Legends set, is that the Elder Dragon Cycle (Nicol Bolas, Chromium Rhuell, et. al.), the 3-colored Legends Cycles (Johan, Xira, Tetsuo), and the other Gold Legends Cycles, ACTUALLY have Comic Books relating their adventures and every character is actually part of a large Dominaria-based Story, mainly dealing with the Rise and Fall of the Madaran Empire of Nicol Bolas.

Now, here's some fun stuff. When it comes to Nicol Bolas, prepare for plotlines and stories to be very long and confusing. :) Two of the legends from Legends, are Sol'Kanar the Swamp King and Dakkon Blackblade. Dakkon didn't participate in the Madaran conflicts, (to my knowledge). Where did his Blackblade come from?

From Geyadrone Dihada. Why wasn't she in Legends if she was such an important character? Because she was one of those characters that was Too Powerful for a Card. That's right: She was an Old Planeswalker. There was even an entire Planeswalker War between her and most of the other named Old Planeswalkers that never managed to matter much to the Urza Plotlines. How did Dakkon Blackblade get his sword? Why, she gave it to him. She also gave him apparently-planeswalker like Powers.

Now you might be thinking HOLD THE PHONE. Isn't Bolas a Planeswalker? and if Dakkon is a Planeswalker, why does he get a card? Well, Dakkon Blackblade and Nicol Bolas at the time of these TERRIBLY Ancient events, they had the *ability to planeswalk* as much as the Skyship Weatherlight did, but its unclear whether Dakkon even ever had a Spark, and its Very clear that Bolas' Spark hadn't exactly ignited until the end of the Elder Dragon War. Now the Blackblade is, as you might have guessed, cursed, evil, and something of a trap. Through the manipulating of a number of people and events, the Blackblade changed hands to Sol'Kanar. The Unholy Citadel was Geyadrone Dihada’s huge, mobile fortress, a collection of bones and rubble on spidery legs built by Sol'Kanar the Swamp King (taken straight from Wikipedia) But Dakkon does indeed get his Blackblade back. Except because Dihada is one of those Evil-Witch types, she does lots of trickery, manipulation, and meanness, and manages to set it up that Dakkon has lost his ability to Planeswalk AND he's got to serve her. And there are other characters involved that are related to other important characters who are by now long-dead.

Now here's some more fun History-- during a period of time that my Wikipedia Searching can't pinpoint EXACTLY, but is "Ancient Dominarian", either actually at the END of the Dragon War, or between the Dragon War and the Planeswalker War, Dihada actually killed

One-Third of all the Elder Dragons in the Existence of the Multiverse, including the 6th one that doesn't get a Legends card because MTG is base-5, not base-6, and maybe because by the time Legends happens she's already been killed. Except that would mean Chromium is also dead as of before the Madaran Empire stuff even happens, so why does he get a card? Because Blue needs an Elder Dragon.

And, in fact, it's BECAUSE her hand in the deaths of so many of Nicol Bolas' blood relatives kind of gets unavoidably brought up, that the Planeswalker War ignites on the Null Moon, which is kind of like a cross between an Entmoot and 20th century Europe, because Planeswalkers don't like each other as much as Ents do, and the Elder Dragon Piru is basically Archduke Ferdinand.

You can waste probably a straight week looking up all the stories of Legends. =D I never even got to explaining what's so important about Ulgrotha! But in fact, HOMELANDS is very much tied to the tale of both Legends, and the whole Kamigawa Block, because Tetsuo Umezawa, of the Madaran Empire, is the Champion of Nicol Bolas......and the great-great-long-something-great-grandson of Toshiro Umezawa. Also the Moxen of Alpha, (yeah, THE Moxen) were used as kind of a Lighthouse to call the Entmoot of Planeswalkers of the Null Moon.

At which Dihada was in attendance.

So, just WHEN THE HELL do the Legends, Homelands, Antiquities, Kamigawa, and....uhhh...Freaking ALPHA sets take place? In relation to each other?

Like....umm....I dunno Dude

look up Ravidel

This is why we had a Mending XD

3998: Marsh Viper.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
3998: Marsh Viper.text_parsed:
My brother put together a poison deck back in the day, and this guy figured largely into it. It wasn't anything too fancy - he played lots of poison creatures and swung with them; occasionally, he would use a Runed Arch to really ruin someone's day.

The most notable thing about this guy is that he gives multiple poison counters in one shot, which was not something that any of the other creatures in the deck did. It was definitely not typical to feel menaced by a 1/2, but he was certainly threatening when he did hit play.

Nowadays MaRo has brought us Infect, which is more up-to-date poison, and it costed far more aggressively, giving players who love the poison mechanic more competitive tools to work with. Still, Marsh Viper used to be among a poison deck's best weapons, and it deserves some credit for that.

PS: "Powerspawning! You'll have so many babies! 400 BABIES!"

Anyways, this card has the bonus of also getting Dryad Arbor, Murmuring Bosk, and Sapseep Forest, even if they don't benefit as much from hitting the battlefield untapped.

The most sadly hilarious thing about this card is that the flavor is so completely wrong.

The only things that actually distinguish a tarpan as a tarpan are the fact that it was gray with a black mane and tail and that it was never domesticated.

So, the art is entirely incorrect and the flavor text is way off-base too. It's kind of surprising because I would think that whoever had enough niche equestrian knowledge to even come up with the idea of a tarpan card would also have known that a tarpan is just a horse species which was never domesticated.

I guess the mechanic represents you eating it?

I suspect this is not because blue is the most effective color (it's not bad, but doesn't really stand out in terms of power to me) but rather that blue is the most annoying to play against, so people remember their losses to blue more.  Blue almost seems designed to *** people off much more then other colors.

4017: Tsunami.author: Aquillion
4017: Tsunami.text_parsed:
@ddde: To be fair, every card in the Power Nine that wasn't an artifact was blue; that probably fueled the perception that Blue is overpowered for the longest time, too. Also, blue's weakness was traditionally that it had weak creatures (excluding a few really expensive fliers) and weak direct creature removal... but early in the game's existence, most creatures were weak anyway, and blue had an undercosted Control Magic that really didn't leave it feeling weak to creatures.

Blue really was pretty clearly the most powerful color back in Unlimited.

(Also, a lot of early mechanics in blue were later moved elsewhere. Deflection, for example, is bizarrely a red power when it's appeared on more modern cards. There has been a tendency by WotC to just throw any oddball powers onto blue.)

4017: Tsunami.author: blurrymadness
4017: Tsunami.text_parsed:
Blue, at the casual level, is basically fine. It has an answer to everything, but it has to be well built for those answers to make sense, matter, and not die before getting a win con on the board.

Blue at the competitive level; however; often has some of the best creatures ever printed (Delver of Secrets, True-Name) or will splash for them; while running 5 lands less than the other colors due to Brainstorm and Ponder. Blue also not only has had some bleed into literally every kind of thing in magic (permanent destruction, exile cards, grave hate, discard, draw, counters, efficient creatures, etc..) but it's the number one requirement for reliable combo decks. They have the best planeswalker; closely followed by black. They have dominated block after block. (Blue Devotion, Delver, Snapcaster, Jace, etc..) Blue decks are nearly always good despite all the power-seep complaints.

As of this post; 6 of the top 10 cards in Legacy are monoblue (you would expect 1-2), 2 of the 10 are hate against blue; including Red Elemental Blast. If blue isn't so dominating; why is Red Elemental Blast one of the *top 10 cards?*

Aside from that huge tangent; this is a reasonable hate card against Counterbalance Divining Top (Countertop) decks; as they only have a few 4-cost cards in the deck; and if it resolves they basically lose.

4019: Venom.author: Calcheesmo
4019: Venom.text_parsed:
Ok, question:

I was recently playing a game and got into an argument (scratch that, friendly debate) over this.

I had the classic Lure+Venom combo on a 1/1 creature. My opponent had out 5 creatures including one with first strike.

Ok, so I declare attackers, my 1/1 Lure+Venom and a few others.

He declares blockers...all of his untapped creatures being forced to block my 1/1 Lure+Venom.

His first strike creature kills my 1/1 and it is dead, thus dealing no damage to his creatures. BUT his creatures were all forced to block, thus should be dead from venom correct?

Venom ISN'T Deathtouch, Deathtouch requiring combat damage. Venom is merely blocking creatures...so if his creatures don't deal or aren't dealt damage, but are still declared blockers (due to lure) do they all die?
4019: Venom.text_posted:
Ok, question:

I was recently playing a game and got into an argument (scratch that, friendly debate) over this.

I had the classic Lure+Venom combo on a 1/1 creature.  My opponent had out 5 creatures including one with first strike.

Ok, so I declare attackers, my 1/1 Lure+Venom and a few others.

He declares blockers...all of his untapped creatures being forced to block my 1/1 Lure+Venom.

His first strike creature kills my 1/1 and it is dead, thus dealing no damage to his creatures.  BUT his creatures were all forced to block, thus should be dead from venom correct?

Venom ISN'T Deathtouch, Deathtouch requiring combat damage.  Venom is merely blocking creatures...so if his creatures don't deal or aren't dealt damage, but are still declared blockers (due to lure) do they all die?

4019: Venom.author: Phelplan
4019: Venom.text_parsed: @Calcheesmo  The way the card is worded: Yes, all of your friend's creatures die.  No combat damage needs to be dealt; only the "blocked" requirement needs to be met for the Venom to take effect.
4019: Venom.text_posted: @Calcheesmo  The way the card is worded: Yes, all of your friend's creatures die.  No combat damage needs to be dealt; only the "blocked" requirement needs to be met for the Venom to take effect.

Significantly worse than Argothian Enchantress, but modern playable. Since replaced with Mesa Enchantress. Kor Spiritdancer also serves a similar purpose and is better in aura-centric decks. This printing has my least favorite art and flavor text of any of the four. Still a good card that pulls its weight in an enchantment based deck. Not yet out as I write this is the similar Eidolon of Blossoms, which some decks may prefer as for 1 more mana it cantrips and triggers other, similar effects.

4029: Ambush Party.author: DarthParallax
4029: Ambush Party.text_parsed:
It's not a direct French Vanilla...

A French Hill Giant is a 3/2 with Haste for 4.

And it doesn't have enough Value to be a German Chocolate...

A Chocolate Hill Giant is a 4/3 with First Strike and Trample for 6 mana.

This is....

An Irish Cream. Irish Cream cards are cards that have a variety of very French Vanilla abilities with remixed power, toughness, and mana costs of recognizable Vanilla Creatures. Like a Vanilla Flier that was tweaked up with abilities like Defender or First Strike, or a Vanilla Reacher that's given Deathtouch, a Vanilla Haste creature given either First Strike or Trample or a Vanilla Vigilance creature given Lifelink.


A Hazelnut Coffee creature is a card that you would give 3 or 4 stars on Gatherer, but NOT 4.5 or more, and are based on French Vanilla and Irish Cream design, and DOESN'T have so much Chocolate value that you'd be upset to see it at common in Limited, where playing with "Low Tech" and still winning is actually pretty fun! :D

"Fair but Good" Commons/"Normal" Uncommon

4031: Ball Lightning.author: Silverware
4031: Ball Lightning.text_parsed:
Ball lightning is an amazing card that really fits into red. It can be very risky to play due to pingers who can kill it before it even attacks, and pretty much any card that deals at least one damage at instant speed. Also creatures with firststrike really ruin ball lightnings day. But when you get past all the little problems that can present themselves as threats for ball lightning it is pure undeniable power.

I have seen three ball lightnings hit the field in one turn and it was gg right then and there.
It is one of thouse few older cards that has actully aged well. R&D knows that this card is loved by many, infact that is why it has seen so many reprints and knock offs. Put simply it is a classic.

Also, if you love Ball Lightning and you perfer to play green (possibly for the mana excel) consider groundbreaker.
